review.title: Asking too much? The rhetorical role of questions in political discourse
review.abstract: Questions play a prominent role in social interactions, performing rhetorical functions that go beyond that of simple informational exchange. The surface form of a question can signal the intention and background of the person asking it, as well as the nature of their relation with the interlocutor. While the informational nature of questions has been extensively examined in the context of question-answering applications, their rhetorical aspects have been largely understudied.

metadata.title: Asking too much? The rhetorical role of questions in political discourse

sections.text: In this work, we introduce an uncontrolled methodology to extract recurring surface motifs in questions and group them according to their latent rhetorical role. By applying this framework to Question Time in the British Parliament, we show that the resulting typology encodes key aspects of political discourse - such as the split in question behavior between government and opposition parties - and reveals new insights into the impact of an MP's term of office and political career ambitions.

sections.text: The second component of our frameworks is the space of questions about their functional roles, which extend beyond the question of why. The main thing is that the way a question is answered provides a good indication of its intention. So, if two questions are formulated differently but answered in a similar way, the parallels that result from their answers are pushed into the background; the second question is whether the question about the why is a question at all; the third question is whether the question about the why is a question at all; the third question is whether the question about the why is an answer at all; and the third question is whether the question about the why is an answer at all.

sections.heading: 7 Career Trajectory Effects
sections.text: We use our framework to gain further insight into the nature of political discourse in Parliament by focusing on how a Member's behaviour in the institution changes. As explained in the introduction, two alternative hypotheses emerge: younger Members may be more critical out of enthusiasm, but they are potentially weakened by their participation in future promotion opportunities compared to older Members; older Members, who are less at risk of further promotion opportunities, may ask more antagonistic questions; young and old Members refer to tenure - i.e., how many years someone has served as an MP - rather than the biological age.

sections.heading: 8 Conclusion and Future Work
sections.text: We have instantiated and validated our approach to parliamentary question time frames and demonstrated new interactions between question behavior and career paths. We note that our methodology is not tied to a particular area. metadata.abstractText: Questions play a prominent role in social interactions, performing rhetorical functions that go beyond that of simple informational exchange. The surface form of a question can signal the intention and background of the person asking it, as well as the nature of their relation with the interlocutor. While the informational nature of questions has been extensively examined in the context of question-answering applications, their rhetorical aspects have been largely understudied. In this work we introduce an unsupervised methodology for extracting surface motifs that recur in questions, and for grouping them according to their latent rhetorical role. By applying this framework to the setting of question sessions in the UK parliament, we show that the resulting typology encodes key aspects of the political discourse—such as the bifurcation in questioning behavior between government and opposition parties—and reveals new insights into the effects of a legislator’s tenure and political career ambitions.
